Gets visibly shaken and nervous when spotting Lucy and Elliot, leading to repeated phrases and stammering.
Improvises awkwardly with incorrect or absurd statements about the car, such as mentioning 'two solid metal doors' and 'optional tires'.
Attempts to continue the presentation despite losing composure, showing some resilience.
Angrily reprimands for leaving the refrigerator open, but then notices Elliot's injury and promptly offers help by getting ice for his eye.
Engages in lighthearted, friendly banter with Elliot, laughing and showing appreciation for his energy.
Joins in a kiss unexpectedly but then sets a clear boundary.
Brushes off romantic advances insisting she has no time for romance and is focused on her daughter.
Asks politely for a paper towel while washing off makeup.
Realizes she has makeup on her face and tries to wash it off quickly but only manages to remove half of it.
Firmly tells Elliot to not kiss her again and resists romantic advances while maintaining her boundary.
Admits she has no time for romance because she is focused on taking care of her daughter’s health.
Kisses sleeping child goodnight after reading note.
Cautiously searches for Elliot on dark, quiet roof, showing concern.
Smiles at the note and shares a tender moment with Elliot, dances with him despite uncertainty.
Tiptoes to not wake Lucy, tries to be considerate of her.
Glances apprehensively at Lucy while cooking, then sits next to her to eat quietly, showing concern and attempts to provide comfort.
Tells Elliot not to call Lucy 'kid' because she doesn't like it, advocating for her feelings.
Shows concern for Lucy’s fear and shares her own fear about repeating past pain.
Expresses vulnerability openly, admitting scared feelings and emotional uncertainty.
Wants Elliot to express affection and engage emotionally, but resists physical closeness when offered.
Backs away from physical affection and states emotional exhaustion with love, showing resistance to intimacy.
Tells Elliot to pack his things and leave, stating 'Nothing personal.'
Paula starts to cry after Elliot slams the door.
Expresses anger and insists last night was important to her when Elliot makes light of it.
Calls Elliot 'the silliest man I ever met' in a dismissive tone.
Paula stops Elliot from putting his suitcase on the bed, showing attentiveness and a practical approach.
Paula hesitates and is silent after Elliot leaves the room, showing some uncertainty before deciding to enter his room.
Openly admits her nervousness and embarrassment about moving in with a partner, asks for encouragement.
Acknowledges past failures in school but expresses belief that this relationship is different and positive.
Takes charge of the painting by insisting on the exact color she wants, actively participates in decorating by putting up curtains and overseeing the room setup.
More focused on the room than on Elliot's affectionate gesture, showing possible emotional distance or distraction.
Comes home carrying gifts (two large lamps) excited and happy, immediately notices Lucy looking glum and asks her sincerely what's wrong.
Paula shows visible distress and panic upon hearing about Elliot's sudden trip and job opportunity.
Despite her internal struggle, Paula expresses happiness and support for Elliot's opportunity.
Paula tries to comfort Elliot when he admits his fear and insecurity.
Paula does not argue or dismiss Elliot’s excitement and fears, instead listens and responds patiently.
Offers help and shows emotional sensitivity, but reacts passively to Elliot's decision and frustration.
Accepts Elliot's decision to go despite her doubts without asserting her own position strongly.
Wishes Elliot well sincerely, promising to keep fingers crossed for his success.
Shows acceptance of Elliot leaving and personal growth, expressing strength and resilience.
Responds to Lucy's inability to sleep with a glum, somewhat dismissive comment 'Give it five minutes...'

Lets the phone ring initially before answering, hesitant but ultimately agrees to go with Elliot, expresses emotional vulnerability with teary acceptance, insists on contributing by working and caring about their apartment
Shows some reluctance and hesitation to immediately respond to Elliot's call and invitation

Questions Elliott about the situation, showing some engagement but also confusion.
Expresses reluctance and emotional vulnerability instead of decisiveness when asked to come along.
Mentions practical concerns about Lucy and work despite emotional distractions.
